comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The hall at the end was a RC church from the mid 19th C. until 1903. I don't see a cross on top of it so I think it's probably after that.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Excellent, so post-1903 then! And thank you, I thought that might have been a courthouse or similar...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Ah the typical county council road worker picture 3 men in the hole digging and at least 6 0nlookers!! Mike Murphy would be proud.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: And sure we may as well have the google streetview link: maps.google.ie/maps?q=roscommon+town&hl=en&ll=53....

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The house on the corner is of a style that if I saw it in Kiel or Hamburg, I'd date at between 1890 and 1910. Does anyone have a date for its erection?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Actually, a bit of messing with the image characteristics makes the spike on top of Harrison Hall look a lot more like a cross seen end on. It may still be a church in this picture after all.

comment.author: 12822629@N02
comment._content:
Things havnt changed much in roscommon!!
The building at the end of the street is now the Bank Of Ireland

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Here is the OSI map, it looks like the butcher shop (second building on the left) was added between the map survey and our picture, now if I can remember how to get the survey date of the map it might help, also the building on the corner does not look like the correct shape to that in the map, so perhaps a new build too...OSI 25

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: No luck there the map was surveyed on 1st July 1891

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Talking about the Butcher at the door, he is peeking menacingly at the sheep for sale to his right!!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: 1911 Census has a Petrick Dolan, General Merchant, in house no 5 main Street 1911 Census

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: 1911 Census also has a butcher Shop at house No1 Main Street House no 1 James Feeley, Butcher Shop House no 2 Edward Fallon, Public House House no 3 John Mannion, Shop House no 4 Bridget Henry, Shop House no 5 Patrick Dolan, General Merchant (as above) Details Here Cant find any of the above for positive in the 1901 census???

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Hayden Monument is 1895 - 1905 (circa 1900) but would be key if we could find exact date.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: The inscription on the monument recalls Luke Hayden's death.  He died 23 Jun 1897.  So it is after this date.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Feeley was a butcher in 1905 link text

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: On the crennellations visible behind the hall: "Having served as a jail for less than a century, it subsequently became a lunatic asylum, then a refuge for smallpox sufferers, a market house and later a private house."

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] so I give up on this one, best guess at date is after the memorial per [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward]  say 1900 (to give them some time to bury Mr Hayden and get the committee together to build the memorial) and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] point on the corner house being between 1890 and 1910 is not correct, I saw somewhere it was built pre 1880. so current before date is still unknown.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Are you sure? It doesn't match either the historic 6" or the historic 25" very well, and the render still looks damp in that photo, though that could be the weather, I suppose.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Plus you've got the brownfield site shown on the 25" map that's a house in this picture. Does that not put it post 1891?

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I hear what you say, but have a look at this. China Palace Restaurant, Main Street, Church Street, Roscommon, County Roscommon and Memorial as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] says is def after June 1897

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Fair enough.

comment.author: 78860124@N07
comment._content: Hi all. I'm 99% certain this photo was taken in 1903. It is known that Robert French visited Roscommon town in 1903 to photograph the dedication of The Sacred Heart Church and so it is very likely that this photo was taken during this visit.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/78860124@N07]  Hard to argue against 1903

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/78860124@N07] Well if you think it's from some specific event, we can see if it lines up with the solar calculator. The shadows are pretty clear. What's the date for the dedication? 
(The solar calcualtor is putting this pretty near the middle of June, I think).

comment.author: 78860124@N07
comment._content: The dedication took place on the 18th of June 1903.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Well, there's certainly no contradictory evidence in the shadows.

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content: I am sure there is a parked bike or bikes on the kerb side some where behind all those horse and carts.
